page.title: 08GEOLOGY AND ECOLOGY
page.content: The buildings and roads are mostly built on the Marlestone platform (middle lias) because the limestone soil is too hard to grow much on it. Above this level is the Stinchcombe Hill escarpment. On the Inferior Dolite on the plateau top is rough pasture and the Golf Club. Beech woods grow on the Cotteswold Sands of the steep sides of the hill. It would be difficult to grow trees on the top because of the weather. The canopy of branches and leaves allows only small shrubs to grow. The roots come up to the surface of the soil because there isn't much goodness underneath. The farms and sown grasslands are situated mainly on the gentle slopes and lower lias clays of Dursley, Cam and Stinchcombe, where the land is not too steep to use tractors.
